a b s t r a c t
Based on the unique two-dimensional (2D) planar nanostructure with atomic-thin thickness, abundant composition variations and the corresponding exceptional physiochemical/biological performances, the emerging inorganic 2D nanomaterials with high biocompatibility have been becoming one of the most promising material nanosystems of great potentials for applications in biomedicine. This review focuses on the unique photothermal-conversion property of several new representative 2D nanomaterials beyond graphene for photothermal conversion-based tumor hyperthermia and theranostic biomedicine, including transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs, such as MoS2, WS2, TiS2 and Bi2Se3), black phosphorous (P), metal Pd nanosheets and their composite nanosheets. Based on high photothermal-conversion efficiency of these 2D nanomaterials, this review first highlights the design, synthesis and surface functionalization of 2D nanomaterials for photothermal therapy (PTT) ablation of cancer cells/tissues. The representative strategies of functionalizing these 2D nanomaterials for imaging-guided PTT and PTTbased synergistic cancer therapy are then discussed. The preliminary progresses on biosafety evaluation of these 2D nanomaterials were also briefly summarized and discussed. Finally, we discussed the state-ofart unsolved critical issues and challenges, and outlooked further research directions of 2D nanomaterials for potential clinical translation for PTT tumor ablation. It is believed that the fast development and promising performance of these biocompatible 2D materials can provide a highly efficient nanoplatform for combating cancer by hyperthermia.

Hyperthermia as an efficient cancer-treatment modality has ttracted broad research attentions of scientific community on ccount of its high efficiency for cancer-cell killing and specific role or enhancing the therapeutic outcome of other treatment modalties, such as chemotherapy and radiotherapy [1]. For thermal reatment of diseases, it is facile to realize site-specific heatng effect where only the lesion tissues can be heated while he temperature of normal organs and tissues keeps at normal evel. Various heating modalities have been developed to generte the hot regions in tumors, including focused ultrasound [2–4], adiofrequency [5], magnetic field [1,6], microwave [7], light [8,9], tc. Comparatively, photothermal therapy (PTT) features low cost, ite-specific therapy, mitigated side effects and relatively high effiiency [10]. However, light-induced thermal treatment suffers from he difficulties/challenges of high light absorption of normal tisues and low light-penetration depth, which reduce the heating fficiency and cause the non-specific damage to normal tissue long light-propagation path. Fortunately, recent developments of ano-biotechnology provide a highly efficient and versatile stratgy to overcome above-mentioned critical issue to large extents. anoparticles (NPs) with high photothermal-conversion efficiency re introduced into tumor tissues, which can be activated by ight at reduced laser intensity/power density and specific laser
avelength in the first (700–980 nm) and second (1000–1400 nm) iological window [11–15]. As a result, such NPs-assisted PTT trategies can simultaneously increase the tumor-ablation efficacy nd mitigate the side effect during the hyperthermia process.
Metal NPs such as Au nanorods, nanocages, nanostars and anoshells have been extensively developed as the earliest candiates for photothermal cancer ablation, but their optical properties re substantially influenced by their particle size, morphology, hotothermal stability and even surrounding microenvironment 13,16–18]. Carbon-based nanosystems including mesoporous caron [19–21], carbon nanodots[22,23] and graphene [24,25] were lso explored in biomedical applications, especially in phototheral therapy based on their strong light absorption in NIR region and orresponding high photothermal-conversion efficiency [26]. Some rganic, inorganic and their hybrid nanosystems, such as polypyrole [27], indocyanine green[28], conductive polymers [29], CuS 30,31], Prussian blue [32], WOx [33], black TiO2 [34] and other rganic polymer/molecules[35,36] also provide alternative phoothermal agents for PTT.
Most of reported photothermal agents are in spherical or od-like morphology [13,16,17,37–42]. The loading capability and fficiency of these solid nanosystems are severely limited though ome cage-like shape can be created within the matrix. Fortunately, ecent results have demonstrated that inorganic two-dimensional 2D) nanosheets with ultrathin atomic thickness, controllable ateral size, and extremely large surface area exhibit unique physochemical properties suitable for a broad range of applications, specially in biomedicine such as drug/gene delivery [43–45], iagnostic imaging [46,47], photothermal/photodynamic therapy 38], biosensing[48] and even tissue engineering [49]. Compared o traditional photothermal agents, these 2D nanosheets feature ow toxicity, easy surface modification and high photothermalonversion efficiency at the wavelength within the biological indow. Graphene-based 2D nanosheets have been extensively xplored as the efficient photothermal agents for tumor hyperhermia [50]. However, graphene oxide or reduced graphene suffer rom potential toxicity and extremely low biodegradation, similar
Please cite this article in press as: Y. Chen, et al., Two-dimensional non therapy, Nano Today (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016
o the toxicity of carbon nanotubes [51–53]. In addition, their phoothermal efficiency should be further improved to enhance the blation outcome, which is relatively difficult to realize because f their single carbonaceous composition. The fast development
PRESS xxx (2016) xxx–xxx
of 2D materials recently catalyzes the emergence of a new noncarbonaceous 2D material family with high biocompatibility and enhanced photothermal-conversion efficiency, mainly including transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), black phosphorous, metals and their corresponding composites (Fig. 1a). These 2D materials can be easily synthesized either by liquid exfoliation from their bulk crystals (up-down method) or growth from corresponding precursors in solution (bottom-up approach, Fig. 1a) [54–66]. The up-down approach can produce 2D nanosheets with very few defects in the materials, but it is difficult to control the morphology and uniformity of nanosheets by the exfoliation process. Comparatively, the bottom-up approach can fabricate 2D nanosheets with desirable morphology, size, dispersity and even surface modification, but it is still challenging to synthesize 2D nanosheets with single atomic-layer thickness and few defects by the bottom-up strategy, which are more suitable for biomedical applications. Importantly, either abundant chemical composition variations or subsequent functionalization processes can endow these 2D photothermal agents with bio-imaging property, i.e., these multifunctional 2D nanomateirals possess theranostic functions (concurrent diagnostic imaging and therapy) [67]. In addition, these new 2D nanosystems can realize high synergistic therapy (Fig. 1a), such as combined PTT/chemotherapy and PTT/radiation therapy (RT). As a matter of fact, a large number of 2D material nanosystems have been developed with rich composition variations and multi-facet physiochemical properties, which can circulate within the blood vessels and accumulate into tumor tissue. Upon external laser irradiation, these 2D nanosheets can convert the photo energy into thermal energy, increase the local tumor temperature and cause the tumor ablation (Fig. 1b). When they are designed and chosen for biomedical hyperthermia applications, a careful consideration should be kept in mind that there should be a good balance between biosafety and photothermal performance of these 2D materials while the biosafety is the priority (Fig. 1b). The chosen 2D materials must be highly biocompatible so that they can be potentially developed for further clinical translation. If they are toxic, it will be impossible for clinical translation no matter how high their PTT efficiency could reach.
Based on the fast development of new 2D materials for biomedicine, herein we highlight and discuss the very recent progresses on the design, synthesis, functionalization and photothermal applications of new emerging non-carbonaceous 2D nanomaterials, focusing on their unique structure/compositionproperty relationships in tumor hyperthermia. The biosafety issues regarding short- and long-term biocompatibility evaluation of these 2D materials is briefly discussed, with a careful consideration of their structure/composition control to satisfy the practical-application requirements. Especially, the research obstacles/challenges and future developments of these promising 2D nanomaterials for clinical translation are discussed and outlooked.
Transition metal dichalcogenides
Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) are a new family of 2D nanosheets typically in the form of MX2 where M is the transition metal and X is the chalcogen [54,62,68]. The diverse composition choice of TMDCs enables this new material family with distinguished electronic, optical and catalytic properties, which underpin a broad spectrum of applications in energy, environmental and biomedical areas [57,69–74]. Recent results have demonstrated that certain members of TMDCs were fea-

Most MoS2 nanosheets were fabricated via top-down liquid exfoliation methodology from their bulk crystals. The ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets not only can act as the photothermal agent for PTT, but also function as the drug-delivery nanocarriers for chemotherapeutic agents based on their large surface area [113]. As a paradigm, an improved oleum-treatment exfoliation strategy was recently developed to fabricate 2D MoS2 nanosheets followed by surface-chitosan (CS) modification (Fig. 2a) [102]. The CSmodified MoS2 nanosheets (designated as MoS2-CS) were further demonstrated to act as NIR-triggered multifunctional nanosystem with concurrent capabilities of PTT and heat-accelerated local drug releasing. The ultrathin sheet-like shape provided abundant anchoring points to achieve high anticancer drug (doxorubicin, DOX)-loading efficiency (Fig. 2b and c) and amount (Fig. 2d). Importantly, NIR irradiation increased the microenvironment temperature of the nanosheets, further accelerating the releasing of DOX from the carrier substantially (Fig. 2e). The NIR-induced PTT

However, the crucial structural parameters of MoS2 nanosheets btained by top-down exfoliation are difficult to be precisely conrolled, and the second tedious surface-modification process is enerally required to guarantee their high stability in physiologcal condition. To solve this critical issue, we recently successfully eveloped a one-pot bottom-up strategy to synthesize PEGylated oS2 nanosheets via an one-pot solvothermal process where the o and S elements-containing precursors were involved (Fig. 2h) 103]. During the solvothermal process at high temperature, MoS2 anosheets with controllable particulate sizes (50 nm, 80 nm, 00 nm, 200 nm and 300 nm, Fig. 2i–m) were easily synthesized nd their surface PEGylation was realized simultaneously. The large planar surface and high surface-to-volume ratio of MoS2 nanosheets could also be adopted for the transport of large biomolecules such as gene due to the features of easy surfaceorganic modification and efficient intracellular uptake, initiating a new gene-delivery nanosystem with 2D nanostructure beyond graphene. As a paradigm, MoS2 surface was co-modified with polyethyleneimine (PEI) and polyethylenglycol (PEG) via reducingresponsive disulfide bonds (designated as MoS2-PEI-PEG) [95]. DNA molecules were anchored onto the surface of MoS2-PEI-PEG to form a stable polyplex (designated as MoS2-PEI-PEG/DNA). The as-synthesized MoS2-PEI-PEG/DNA entered the cells via a typical endocytosis process. Importantly, the photothermal effect of MoS2 nanosheets by NIR irradiation was found to effectively cause the

S2, TiS2 and Bi2Se3 nanosheets
By optimizing the composition of 2D TMDCs, they could act as heranostic agents for imaging-guided PTT ablation of tumor. For nstance, WS2 nanosheets (Fig. 4a) with high-content W compoent are favorable for CT imaging due to high atomic number (Z) of

demonstrated to be effective in photothermal conversion for tumor hyperthermia (Fig. 4b) [114]. In addition, their exceptional photoacoustic responsiveness endows them with PA imaging-guided photothermal potential (Fig. 4b1). Ti component in TiS2 was considered to be more biocompatible compared to Mo and W elements in MoS2 and WS2, respectively, because Ti-based biomaterials have found extensive clinical applications. TiS2 nanosheets were prepared by a bottom-up approach, during which TiC4 precursor reacted with sulfur powder at high temperature. The particle size of as-synthesized TiS2 nanosheets was around 100 nm (Fig. 4b2). Their surface was further PEGylated via a hydrophobic interaction between PEG molecules and TiS2 surface. Especially, the extinction coefficient of TiS2-PEG at 808 nm was determined to be as high as 26.8 Lg−1 cm−1, comparable to MoS2 and WS2 nanosheets. The high PA-imaging capability of TiS2 nanosheets was demonstrated after intravenous administration of TiS2-PEG nanosheets where strong contrast-enhanced PA signals were observed within the whole tumor, showing the imaging-guidance capability. In vivo evaluation on photothermal efficiency showed that the tumor temperature increased quickly after intravenous administration of TiS2-PEG nanosheets followed by 808 nm laser irradiation (0.8 W/cm2, 5 min). The tumor growth was drastically inhibited (Fig. 4b3) and the survival rate was substantially improved (Fig. 4b4). The tumor was almost completely removed after photothermal ablation assisted by TiS2-PEG (Fig. 4b5). Besides, bismuth selenide (Bi2Se3) nanosheets (Fig. 4c) with particulate size of around 90 nm

Metal Pd nanosheets
Metal NPs, such as Au and Ag, have been extensively employed as the photothermal agents due to their unique surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect [16,39,40,126–128]. To overcome the drawbacks of low photothermal stability of conventional plasmonic Au and Ag NPs, metal palladium (Pd) nanosheets with strong NIR SPR absorption and enhanced photothermal stability were synthesized by a generic CO-confined growth approach [124]. Highly crystallized Pd nanosheets exhibited typical nanoflake topological morphology with monodispersity and regular hexagon shape, and their edge length was controlled from 20 to 160 nm (Fig. 7a–d), highly suitable for in vivo translations. The thickness of Pd nanosheets was only 1.8 nm, less than 10 atomic layers thick. These ultrathin hexagonal Pd nanosheets exhibited tunable and strong SPR absorption (826–1068 nm) with the extinction coefficient of 4.1 × 109 M−1cm−1 (Fig. 7e). Especially, as-synthesized Pd nanosheets were highly stable upon NIR irradiation. 2. D composite nanosheets
Inorganic-inorganic composite nanosheets
The integration of 2D nanosheets with functional inorganic components to form 2D composite nanosheets can bring with new funcitonalities to facilely realize imaging-guided PTT and/or PTT-based synergsitic tumor treatment. Typically, these are three strategies to realize this purpose. First, the large surface area offered by 2D nanosheets leaves sufficient room for loading of funcitonal nanocrystals where 2D nanosheets act as the substrate. Second, the framework of these 2D nanosheets can be doped with heterogenous elements for diagnostic imaging. Third, the flexible 2D naosheets could coat onto the surface of nanocrystals to form core/shell nanoparticles.
The integration of 2D nanosheets with other drug carriers towards multifunctionalization can also endow them with synergistic functions for simultaneous PTT and chemotherapy (Fig. 8a). Pd nanosheets were coated onto the surface of hollow mesoporous silica spheres (HMSS) via electrostatic interation (Fig. 8a1) between positively charged HMSS-NH2 ( = +29.2 mV) and negatively charged Pd nanosheet ( = −13.3 mV) [145]. A uniform layer of Pd nanosheets was found on the surface of HMSS (Fig. 8a2, 14 Pd nanosheets on each HMSS-NH2). Such an integration of Pd nanosheets endowed HMSS with strong NIR-absorption capability. Upon laser irradiaiton (808 nm, 1 W/cm2), the temperature of aqueous solution (1 mL) quickly rose from 27.0 ◦C to 47.5 ◦C at the HMSS-NH2@Pd concentration of 200 g/mL. The hollow structure and well-defined mesopores of HMSS-NH2@Pd was used as the drug (DOX) delivery nanosystem with a drug-loading capacity of 9.2%. The release kinetic of DOX from the carrier exhibited pH-dependent manner, and the exposure of carrier to NIR laser irradiation (808 nm, 1 W/cm2) fast acceletrated the drug-releasing rates due to the photothermal effect of Pd nanosheets. Cytotoxicity assay showed that the combination of chemotherapeutic effect of loaded DOX drugs and photothermal effect of coated Pd nanosheets brought with the synergistically therapeutic indexes with enhanced efficiency against Hep G2 cancer cells (Fig. 8a3). Similarly, Zheng et al. also realized the multifunctionalization of Pd@Ag nanoplate-based core/shell architecture by directly cotaing a mesoporous silica shell onto the surface of Pd@Ag for pH- and light-controlled dual-responsive drug releasing [146].

Further PEGylation was carried out to improve the stability of doped WS2 nanosheets in physiological solution. As a paradigm, Gd3+-doped WS2 nanosheets (designated as WS2:Gd3+) were demonstrated to be highly effective in cancer theranostics, including triple diagnostic imaging and synergistic PTT and RT. FDA-approved PLGA could be easily dissolved into an biocompatible organic N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) solvent, in which MoS2 nanosheets was dispersed and anticancer drug DOX was concurrently dissolved, forming PLGA/MoS2/DOX (designated as PMD) composite oleosol. When this injectable PMD oleosol was injected into aqueous solution, the NMP solvent quickly diffused into surrounding solution, after which hydrophobic PLGA in-situ formed a solid implant containing MoS2 nanosheets and DOX drugs (Fig. 11a). The as-formed PMD implant firmly restricted within tumor tissue. After 808 nm laser irradiation, the photothermal effect of encapsulated MoS2 nanosheets quickly raised the temperature of surrounding solution (Fig. 11b and c), and accelerated the DOX releasing from PMD implant (Fig. 11d). The in-situ formed PMD implant induced high synergistic-therapeutic effect combining PTT and chemotherapy, causing the significant inhibition of tumor growth (Fig. 11e). Importantly, the as-formed PMD implant is biodegradable with the implanting time. It is also noted that such an injection mode based on liquid-solid phase-changing implants can firmly restrict the photothermal agents within the tumor tissue, thus the cytotoxicity to normal organs is significantly mitigated [6].

Conclusions and outlook

Considering the infancy nature of this research area, there are still numbers of unsolved critical issues and challenges to conquer for future clinical translations. The biodegradation and excretion issue of these 2D nanosystems are considered to be among the biggest challenges to tackle with. It is also considered hat the improvement of biodegradability may cause the releasng of metal ions, which is potentially toxic to human bodies at levated dosages. To solve this issue, one of the possible strateies is to reduce the whole particle sizes of these 2D nanosheets nto extremely small range, which will be easily excreted from the ody via renal system after the therapeutic process. This strategy lears the 2D nanomaterials out of the body via some specific route ather than traditional biodegradation, avoiding the accumulation f nanosheets within the body and the corresponding high toxicity isk of released metal ions. 2D black phosphorous (BP) is not stable n aqueous solution, which means that it can probably biodegrade n physiological condition. However, such structural instability will robably lead to low photothermal stability and storage difficulty. herefore, its stability should be rationally tuned to balance the hotothermal efficiency, stability and biodegradability. This work eviewed several 2D nanosheets suitable for photothermal conersion and PTT against tumor. Each 2D nanosystem is featured ith its intrinsic characteristics for tumor therapy. However, their urther clinical translation strongly relies on their biodegradation, iocompatibility and biosafety. It is highly expected that only the iodegradable 2D nanosheets with high biosafety can quickly enter he clinical stage such as black P and metal oxides though these iological evaluations are still at the very preliminary stage.
The photothermal efficiency should be further improved by ptimizing the nanostructure and composition of these 2D nanoaterials. The PTT outcome should be further enhanced, which ill result in largely reduced particle doses for desirable therpeutic efficiency and substantially improved biosafety of this herapeutic strategy. On one hand, new synthetic methodoloies should be explored to fabricate 2D nanosystems with esirable structure/composition-property relationships and high hotothermal-conversion property. On the other hand, adequate urface modification should be made to guarantee long bloodirculation duration, targeted transport and enhanced tumor ccumulation, which can further improve the PTT efficiency or tumor ablation. Typical PEGylation is effective for realizing hese purposes, but insufficient for satisfactorily efficient delivery. ositive-targeted drug delivery strategies specific to tumor cells is xpected by referencing the targeting strategies of other relatively ature nanosystems in biomedicine, such as liposome, micelle, lbumin and mesoporous silica nanoparticles as well. The exploration of other new 2D nanomaterials for biomedial applications is urgently required [177–186]. Although currently eported 2D nanosystems have been demonstrated to be effecive in PTT for tumor treatment, they are still not considered to e the perfect ones for biomedicine. New 2D nanosystems with ore biocompatible compositions and nanostructures are to be xplored to promote the clinical translation of 2D nanosystems. n addition, the multifunctional and hybridized strategies should e further optimized to endow these 2D nanosystems with more pecific functionalities, not just restricted to conventional MR, CT nd PA imaging [187,188]. Other advanced imaging modalities can e integrated into these 2D nanosystems. Besides chemotherapy nd RT, the photothermal property of 2D nanomaterials can be ombined with other therapeutic modalities, such as ultrasound herapy and microwave therapy, to achieve further enhanced therpeutic efficacies for PTT-based cancer treatments.
This is a highly multidisciplinary research area on the phoothermal applications of new 2D nanomaterials in biomedicine, hich is attracting exponentially increasing attention from chemstry, physics, material science, biology and biomedicine fields.

Yu Chen received his PhD degree at Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences (SICCAS). He is now the professor and Institute Hundred-Talent Fellow in SICCAS. His research includes the design, synthesis and biomedical applications of zero-dimensional organic-inorganic hybrid mesoporous materials, twodimensional nanomaterials and three-dimensional composite implants, including mesoporous material for drug delivery, molecular probes for molecular imaging, ultrasound therapy, non-virus gene delivery vehicles and in-situ localized tumor therapy. He has published over 80 peer-reviewed articles with more than 3600 citations (h-index of 31) and filed 6 national patents.
Lianzhou Wang is currently a professor in School of Chemical Engineering and Research Director of Nanomaterials Centre, the University of Queensland (UQ), Australia. He received his PhD degree from SICCAS in 1999. Before joining UQ in 2004, he has worked at two national institutes (NIMS and AIST) of Japan for five years. Wang’s research interests include the design and application of nanostructured materials including two-dimensional layered compounds for energy, environment and relevant applications.
Jianlin Shi received his PhD degree in SICCAS. He is now the professor of SICCAS. His research areas include synthesis of mesoporous materials and mesoporous-based nano-composites, and their catalytic, biomedical and optical applications. He has published over 400 scientific papers which have been cited more than 15000 times

metadata.abstractText: Based on the unique two-dimensional (2D) planar nanostructure with atomic-thin thickness, abundant composition variations and the corresponding exceptional physiochemical/biological performances, the emerging inorganic 2D nanomaterials with high biocompatibility have been becoming one of the most promising material nanosystems of great potentials for applications in biomedicine. This review focuses on the unique photothermal-conversion property of several new representative 2D nanomaterials beyond graphene for photothermal conversion-based tumor hyperthermia and theranostic biomedicine, including transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs, such as MoS2, WS2, TiS2 and Bi2Se3), black phosphorous (P), metal Pd nanosheets and their composite nanosheets. Based on high photothermal-conversion efficiency of these 2D nanomaterials, this review first highlights the design, synthesis and surface functionalization of 2D nanomaterials for photothermal therapy (PTT) ablation of cancer cells/tissues. The representative strategies of functionalizing these 2D nanomaterials for imaging-guided PTT and PTTbased synergistic cancer therapy are then discussed. The preliminary progresses on biosafety evaluation of these 2D nanomaterials were also briefly summarized and discussed. Finally, we discussed the state-ofart unsolved critical issues and challenges, and outlooked further research directions of 2D nanomaterials for potential clinical translation for PTT tumor ablation. It is believed that the fast development and promising performance of these biocompatible 2D materials can provide a highly efficient nanoplatform for combating cancer by hyperthermia. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd.
